prompt: Hi, I'd like to learn how to play racquetball. Can you explain the game to me?
response:
Here is a basic overview of how to play racquetball:

- Court & Equipment: Racquetball is played indoors on an enclosed court similar in size to a squash or handball court. Players use specially strung racquets and an hollow rubber ball.

- Serving: One player serves the ball by hitting it against the front wall so that it bounces past the short line in the opposite back corner. 

- Returning Serve: The receiving player must let the served ball bounce once before returning it to the front wall above the short line. 

- Playing Rally: After the serve is returned, the ball is hit back and forth between the front and back walls. Players can hit the side or ceiling walls to get angles on shots. 

- Scoring: A point is scored when the opponent fails to return the ball before it bounces twice or hits it out of bounds. The first player/team to reach 15 or 21 points wins the game. 

- Rules: You cannot catch or hold the ball. Carries and hinders (when ball doesn't bounce cleanly after a hit) are not allowed.Safety glasses are recommended due to the ball's high speed.

Let me know if you need any clarification or have additional questions! Proper technique does take some practice, so be patient as you learn the game. Have fun!

Here are the basic steps to draw a hopscotch game on your driveway:

Materials Needed:
- Chalk (sidewalk chalk works best)

1. Clear the area - Sweep or blow away any debris on the driveway where you'll be drawing. You want a clean surface.

2. Draw the baseline - Draw a straight line across the width of the driveway. This will be the starting/ending point. 

3. Draw the boxes - Starting from the baseline, draw 8-10 boxes spaced about 1-2 feet apart in single file up the driveway. Make the boxes about 1 foot square. 

4. Number the boxes - Use the chalk to write the numbers 1-8 (or up to 10) in each box starting from the baseline and moving up the driveway. 

5. Draw extra lines - Optionally, you can draw thinner guide lines between the boxes to help hopping accuracy. 

6. Draw the tossing area - At the end of the line of boxes, draw a larger circle or square where the hopscotch pieces (rocks, etc) will be tossed from. 

7. Add design elements - Get creative by adding shapes, colors or patterns to customize your hopscotch board.

Let the hopping begin! Be sure to sweep or hose off the chalk drawings after play to prolong the game. Have fun! Let me know if any part needs more explanation.

prompt: Explain sarcoidosis to me like I’m a five year old
response:
Okay, here is an explanation of sarcoidosis for a five year old:

Sarcoidosis is a funny word for a sickness some people can get. It happens when your body's defenses get mixed up and start fighting things inside you when they shouldn't. 

Your body has special cells called macrophages that help keep you healthy by fighting off germs like colds and flu. With sarcoidosis, the macrophages get confused and start fighting your own healthy tissues instead of just germs. 

This causes tiny lumps called granulomas to form in different places inside you, like your lungs and lymph nodes. The granulomas are where the macrophages are fighting what they think are germs but are really just your own body. 

Most of the time sarcoidosis doesn't make people feel too sick. But sometimes the lumps can get big and push on organs like your lungs, which can make it hard to breathe. Or the lumps can form in your eyes and cause problems seeing. 

The good news is that sarcoidosis usually goes away on its own after a while. Doctors can give medicine to help make the lumps get smaller faster if they are causing problems. As long as it's treated if needed, sarcoidosis doesn't hurt people for their whole lives. Their body just needs help remembering which cells are friendly and which ones to actually fight!
